#GREENSEEKER CONVERSION

###Getting the linear regression conversion from GreenSeeker_1 to GreenSeeker_2

###From the paper -- "two GreenSeekers were used to measure NDVI in this study (GreenSeeker 1 in 2015 and GreenSeeker 2 from 2016 to 2018). Consistent differences between the two devices were detected by plotting side by side NDVI measurements (n = 105). Differences were normalized by adjusting NDVI values based on the resulting fitted linear regression equation (Fig. S1)."

##Figure S1

```{r}

greenseek_data <- read_csv(file = "greenseeker_comparison.csv")
str(greenseek_data)  

head(greenseek_data)
tail(greenseek_data)

greenseek_data$Greenseeker1 <- (greenseek_data$Greenseeker1_NDVI1 + greenseek_data$Greenseeker1_NDVI2) / 2 #takes average of two readings with Greenseeker1's greenseeker
greenseek_data$Greenseeker2 <- (greenseek_data$Greenseeker2_NDVI1 + greenseek_data$Greenseeker2_NDVI2) / 2 #takes average of two readings with Greenseeker2's greenseeker
str(greenseek_data)

head(greenseek_data)
tail(greenseek_data)

greenmod1 <- lm(Greenseeker2 ~ Greenseeker1 , data = greenseek_data) #creates a linear regression of Greenseeker2 ~ Greenseeker1 greenseeker data

summary(greenmod1) #the resulting equation is Greenseeker2 = -0.02703 + 0.98950 * Greenseeker1 

label_eqn <- paste("y == 0.9895 * x - 0.02703")
label_r2 <- paste("r^2 == 0.77")

greenplot <- ggplot(data = greenseek_data, aes(x = GreenSeeker_1 , y = GreenSeeker_2 )) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(Greenseeker1, Greenseeker2) , data = greenseek_data) +
  geom_smooth( data = greenseek_data , aes(x = Greenseeker1 , y = Greenseeker2 ) , method = lm, formula = y ~ x) +
  annotate("text" , x = 0.78 , y = 0.65 , label = label_eqn , parse = TRUE) +
  annotate("text" , x = 0.78 , y = 0.64 , label = label_r2 , parse = TRUE ) #generates a plot of the data with the model overlayed on the data

greenplot

ggsave("Figure_S1.tiff" , greenplot , device = "tiff" )

```

#DATA

###The following chunk processes the PI NDVI data into a single data frame with only the relevant columns. The N trial data is processed seperately from the Farm Survey data and then merged into a single data frame. 

###N Trial NDVI Data

```{r}

ntrial_data <- read_csv("N_trial_data.csv")

ntrial_data <- ntrial_data[c(1:231), c(1:16)] #removes the extra rows and columns from the data frame

ntrial_data$block <- factor(ntrial_data$block) #changes block to a factor
ntrial_data$plot <- factor(ntrial_data$plot) #changes plot to a factor
ntrial_data$plot_id <- factor(ntrial_data$plot_id)
ntrial_data$N_level <- factor(ntrial_data$N_level)
ntrial_data$exp_plot_number <- factor(ntrial_data$exp_plot_number)
ntrial_data$site_year <- factor(ntrial_data$site_year , levels = c("Arbuckle-15" , "RES-15" , "RES-16" , "Davis-16" , "Nicolaus-17" , "Williams-17","Arbuckle-18" , "Biggs-18" , "Marysville-18" , "Nicolaus-18" )) #changes site-year to a factor
ntrial_data$NDVI_1 <- as.numeric(as.character(ntrial_data$NDVI_1))
ntrial_data$NDVI_2 <- as.numeric(as.character(ntrial_data$NDVI_2))
ntrial_data$NDVI_3 <- as.numeric(as.character(ntrial_data$NDVI_3))
ntrial_data$NDVI_4 <- as.numeric(as.character(ntrial_data$NDVI_4))

str(ntrial_data)

ntrial_data <-  ntrial_data %>% 
  mutate( biomass_dry_wt = biomass_plus_bag_g - (paper_bag_g * num_of_paper_bags) ,
          aboveground_biomass = (biomass_dry_wt / ring_size_m2) / 1000 ,
          n_content = sample_N_ug / sample_weight_mg ,
          N_Uptake = aboveground_biomass * n_content) #processes the data

ntrial_data <- ntrial_data %>% 
  rowwise() %>% 
  mutate(NDVI = mean(c( NDVI_1 , NDVI_2 , NDVI_3 , NDVI_4) , na.rm = T)) #takes average of four NDVI readings

#Greenseeker2 = -0.02703 + 0.98950 * Greenseeker1 Now to normailize the data for the two greenseekers based on the equation we  found earlier


ntrial_data <- ntrial_data %>%
  mutate(NDVI = case_when(site_year == "Arbuckle-15" ~ -0.02703 + 0.98950*NDVI,
                          site_year == "RES-15" ~ -0.02703 + 0.98950*NDVI,
                          site_year == "RES-16" ~ NDVI,
                          site_year == "Davis-16" ~ NDVI,
                          site_year == "Nicolaus-17" ~ NDVI,
                          site_year == "Williams-17" ~ NDVI,
                          site_year == "Nicolaus-18" ~ NDVI,
                          site_year == "Arbuckle-18" ~ NDVI,
                          site_year == "Marysville-18" ~ NDVI,
                          site_year == "Biggs-18" ~ NDVI))

ntrial_data <- dplyr::select(ntrial_data ,
                      site_year,
                    exp_plot_number,
                    block,
                    plot,
                    N_level,
                    aboveground_biomass,
                    n_content,
                    N_Uptake,
                    NDVI) #this takes just the columns were interested in into the next phase of the analysis.

ntrial_data$site_year <- factor(ntrial_data$site_year , levels = c("Arbuckle-15" , "RES-15" , "Davis-16" , "RES-16" , "Nicolaus-17" , "Williams-17" , "Arbuckle-18" , "Biggs-18", "Marysville-18" , "Nicolaus-18")) #orders site-years by year in alphabetical order

```

##MODELS

###Aboveground Biomass Model

```{r}

#lets just plot the data to see what it looks like

ggplot(data = ndvi_data, aes(x = aboveground_biomass , y = NDVI)) +
                    geom_point(mapping = aes(aboveground_biomass, NDVI), data = ndvi_data)
```

```{r}
#nonlinear mixed effects model

gpndvi_data_ab <- groupedData(NDVI ~ aboveground_biomass | site_year, ndvi_data) #makes the ndvi data grouped data

fm1abv.lis <- nlsList(NDVI ~ SSasympOrig(aboveground_biomass , Asym , lrc) | site_year, 
                      data = gpndvi_data_ab)


summary(fm1abv.lis)
plot(fm1abv.lis)

fm1abv.nlme <- nlme(fm1abv.lis) #makes the nlme model from the nlme_lis


summary(fm1abv.nlme)
anova(fm1abv.nlme)
plot(fm1abv.nlme)
plot(resid(fm1abv.nlme, type = "normalized") ~fitted(fm1abv.nlme)) #not the best, but the data itself is hard to model, so I consider this acceptable
plot(fm1abv.nlme, site_year ~ resid(.), abline = 0) # generally consistent across site-years
qqnorm(fm1abv.nlme, abline = c(0,1) )
qqnorm(fm1abv.nlme , ~resid(.) | site_year)
qqnorm(fm1abv.nlme , ~ranef(.))
pairs(fm1abv.nlme, ~ranef(.) , id = 0.1)
plot(ranef(fm1abv.nlme))  #random effects highly correlated.
plot( fm1abv.nlme, resid(., type = "p") ~ fitted(.) | site_year,
      id = 0.05, adj = -0.3 )
qqnorm(fm1abv.nlme, ~ranef(.) , id = 0.10 , cex = 0.7 )
summary(fm1abv.nlme)
errors<- resid(fm1abv.nlme)
shapiro.test(errors) #not normal, but i doubt this relationship would have normal residuals
plot(fm1abv.nlme , NDVI ~ fitted(.) , id = 0.05 , adj = -0.3 , abline = c(0,1))
pairs(fm1abv.nlme , ~ranef(.) | site_year)

fm2abv.nlme <- update(fm1abv.nlme, random = Asym ~1 ) #remove lrc random effect

summary(fm2abv.nlme)

anova(fm2abv.nlme, fm1abv.nlme) #model 1 is better 

fm3abv.nlme <- update(fm1abv.nlme, random = lrc ~1 ) #remove Asym random effect

anova(fm1abv.nlme , fm3abv.nlme) #comparing models 1 and 3, model 1 has slightly lower AIC, but model 3 drops an extra random effect. the lrc and Asym random effect are highly correlated, therefore I believe model 3 is better. 

#checking the model residuals

#fm3abv.nlme <- update(fm3abv.nlme, weights = varIdent(form = ~ 1| site_year))

anova(fm1abv.nlme , fm3abv.nlme)

plot(resid(fm3abv.nlme, type = "normalized") ~fitted(fm3abv.nlme)) #not the best, but the data itself is hard to model, so I consider this acceptable
plot(fm3abv.nlme, site_year ~ resid(.), abline = 0) # generally consistent across site-years
qqnorm(fm3abv.nlme, abline = c(0,1) ) #looks good
qqnorm(fm3abv.nlme , ~resid(.) | site_year) #looks good
qqnorm(fm3abv.nlme , ~ranef(.))
plot(ranef(fm3abv.nlme))
plot( fm3abv.nlme, resid(., type = "p") ~ fitted(.) | site_year,
      id = 0.05, adj = -0.3 )
qqnorm(fm3abv.nlme, ~ranef(.) , id = 0.10 , cex = 0.7 )
summary(fm3abv.nlme)
errors<- resid(fm3abv.nlme)
shapiro.test(errors) #not normal, but i doubt this relationship would have normal residuals
compNup <- compareFits( coef(fm3abv.nlme) , coef(fm1abv.nlme))
plot(compNup , mark = fixef(fm3abv.nlme))
plot(comparePred(fm3abv.nlme , fm1abv.nlme, length.out = 2) , between = list(y = c(0, 0.5)) )
plot(fm3abv.nlme , NDVI ~ fitted(.) , id = 0.05 , adj = -0.3 , abline = c(0,1))
plot(augPred(fm1abv.nlme), level = 1)
abv.comp <- plot(augPred(fm3abv.nlme), level = 1)
abv.comp

#fm3abv.nlme is the model I will select

summary(fm3abv.nlme)
intervals(fm3abv.nlme)

tiff("Figure_S2.tiff")
plot(abv.comp)
dev.off()

#getting the fitted values

fitabv <- fitted(fm3abv.nlme, level = 0)
fit.modabv <- data.frame(ndvi_data$aboveground_biomass , fitabv)

mse.fm3abv.nlme <- mean(residuals(fm3abv.nlme)^2)
mse.fm3abv.nlme
rmse.fm3abv.nlme <- sqrt(mse.fm3abv.nlme)
rmse.fm3abv.nlme

```

###N Concentration Model

```{r}

#just visualize the data

ggplot(data = ndvi_data, aes(x= n_content , y= NDVI)) +
         geom_point(mapping = aes(n_content, NDVI) , data = ndvi_data)

```

```{r}

#nonlinear mixed effects model

gpndvi_data_nc <- groupedData(NDVI ~ n_content | site_year, ndvi_data)

fm1nc.lis <- nlsList(NDVI ~ SSasympOff(n_content, Asym, lrc , c0) | site_year,
                     gpndvi_data_nc)  #make the nLs list object

ctrl <- lmeControl(maxIter = 100)
fm1nc.nlme <- nlme(fm1nc.lis , control = ctrl) #make the nlme

fm2nc.nlme <- update(fm1nc.nlme, weights = varIdent(form = ~ 1| site_year)) #update the variance structure

anova(fm2nc.nlme , fm1nc.nlme) #fm2nc.nlme is better, will stick with it.

plot(resid(fm2nc.nlme, type = "normalized") ~fitted(fm2nc.nlme))
plot(fm2nc.nlme, site_year ~ resid(.), abline = 0)
plot(intervals (fm1nc.lis) , layout = c(3,1))
qqnorm(fm2nc.nlme, abline = c(0,1) )
qqnorm(fm2nc.nlme , ~resid(.) | site_year)
qqnorm(fm2nc.nlme , ~ranef(.))
plot(ranef(fm2nc.nlme))
plot( fm2nc.nlme, resid(., type = "p") ~ fitted(.) | site_year,
      id = 0.05, adj = -0.3 )
qqnorm(fm2nc.nlme, ~ranef(.) , id = 0.10 , cex = 0.7 )
summary(fm2nc.nlme)
x<- resid(fm2nc.nlme)
shapiro.test(x)
plot(augPred(fm2nc.nlme), level = 1)
ncon.comp <- plot(augPred(fm2nc.nlme), level = 1)

intervals(fm2nc.nlme)
summary(fm2nc.nlme)

tiff("Figure_S3.tiff")
plot(ncon.comp)
dev.off()

#getting the fitted values

nonlinfittednc <- fitted(fm2nc.nlme, level = 0)
fitted.modelnc <- data.frame(ndvi_data$n_content , nonlinfittednc)

mse.fm2nc.lme <- mean(residuals(fm2nc.nlme)^2)
mse.fm2nc.lme
rmse.fm2nc.lme <- sqrt(mse.fm2nc.lme)
rmse.fm2nc.lme


```

#YIELD DATA

###Dataframe

###the code below processes the yield data into a single dataframe with the relevant columns. The N Uptake and NDVI data is extracted from the NDVI dataframe. Overall, the steps are pretty obvious. I guess the only thing would be worthy of noting is that "A's" clean grain weight data had already subtracted the paper bag weight, while my data included this value. Thus, tare2 only subtracts the paper bag weight from my data.

```{r}

yield_data <- read_csv("yield_data.csv" )

yield_data$exp_plot_number <- factor(yield_data$exp_plot_number)
yield_data$block <- factor(yield_data$block)
yield_data$plot <- factor(yield_data$plot)
yield_data$plot_id <- factor(yield_data$plot_id)
yield_data$N_level <- factor(yield_data$N_level)
yield_data$site_year <- factor(yield_data$site_year , levels = c("Arbuckle-15" , "RES-15" , "RES-16" , "Davis-16" , "Nicolaus-17" , "Williams-17","Arbuckle-18" , "Biggs-18" , "Marysville-18" , "Nicolaus-18" )) #changes site-year to a factor
str(yield_data)

yield_data$fw1_minus_tare1 <- yield_data$fw1_plus_tare1 - yield_data$tare1 

yield_data$fw2_minus_tare1 <- yield_data$fw2_plus_tare1 - yield_data$tare1

yield_data$fw_net <- yield_data$fw1_minus_tare1 + yield_data$fw2_minus_tare1

yield_data$ss_fw_net <- yield_data$ss_fw_plus_tare1 - yield_data$tare1

yield_data$ratio <- yield_data$ss_fw_net / yield_data$fw_net

yield_data$clean_grain_1 <- yield_data$clean_grain_odw_plus_tare2 - yield_data$tare2

yield_data$clean_grain_2 <- yield_data$yc_clean_grain_odw_plus_tare_3 - yield_data$tare_3

yield_data$clean_grain_2 <- yield_data$clean_grain_2 * yield_data$ratio #this essntially subsamples the yield component samples according to the ratio

yield_data$clean_grain_m2 <- (yield_data$clean_grain_1 + yield_data$clean_grain_2) / yield_data$ratio

yield_data$grain_yield <- yield_data$clean_grain_m2 * 10

yield_data$grain_yield <- yield_data$grain_yield*(98.1/86) #this corrects the grain yield values to 14% moisture

head(yield_data)
tail(yield_data)
str(yield_data)

nup <- data.frame(ndvi_data$site_year , ndvi_data$N_Uptake , ndvi_data$NDVI) #calls the N Uptake values from the NDVI data, this also has Farm Survey values
str(nup)
nup <- nup[!(nup$ndvi_data.site_year == "Farm Survey-15"),] #deletes Farm Survey since it doesnt have yield data
str(nup)
head(nup)
tail(nup)
summary(nup)

yield <- yield_data$grain_yield #calls the grain yield values from yield data


yield_data <- data.frame( nup, yield) #creates a dataframe with these three columns, that are needed for the grain yield ~ n uptake figure
head(yield_data)
tail(yield_data)
colnames(yield_data) <- c(  "site_year" , "n_uptake" , "ndvi" , "yield" )
head(yield_data)


str(yield_data)

yield_data$site_year <- factor(yield_data$site_year , levels = c("Arbuckle-15" , "RES-15" , "Davis-16" , "RES-16" , "Nicolaus-17" , "Williams-17","Arbuckle-18" , "Biggs-18" , "Marysville-18" , "Nicolaus-18" )) #changes site-year to a factor
```

###Model (Yield ~ N Uptake)
```{r}

set.seed(10)

lin.mod <- lm(yield ~ n_uptake, data = yield_data)
segmented.mod <- segmented(lin.mod , seg.Z = ~n_uptake, psi = 9)
summary(segmented.mod)
my.fitted <- fitted(segmented.mod)
my.model <- data.frame(yield_data$n_uptake , my.fitted)
mse.seg.mod<- mean(residuals(segmented.mod)^2)
rmse.seg.mod <- sqrt(mse.seg.mod)
rmse.seg.mod
confint.segmented(segmented.mod)
pscore.test(lin.mod, seg.Z = ~n_uptake, k = 10)

prediction_data <- data.frame(N_Uptake = segmented.mod$psi[2]) #this code predicts the NDVI based on the model using the breakpoint N uptake value
predict(fm2nup.nlme , newdata = prediction_data , level = 0)
```
